etymologies: Middle English; earliest use found in Kentish Sermons. Partly (i) from sun + the present participle of rise

notes.text: Now rare (chiefly archaic or poetic in later use). Largely superseded by sunrise

definitions: The appearance of the sun above the horizon at daybreak.
The time in the morning when the sun appears or full daylight arrives; = "sunrise". Also figurative: = "sunrise".
The region in which the sun rises; the east.

notes.text: Also with modifying word indicating the precise quarter in which the sun rises at a specified season, as "equinoctial sunrising", "winter sunrising".
